metadata.title: Machine Learning Implementation Strategies | by Imran Bangash | Towards Data Science
metadata.description: Edge AI together with Cloud computing architecture is paving the way for the new digital era thanks to recent developments in hardware platforms, hardware accelerators, machine learning

all_paragraphs: Edge AI together with Cloud computing is paving the way for the new digital era thanks to recent developments in hardware platforms, hardware accelerators, machine learning algorithms for edge devices; cloud computing for offline training, data storage and data management. Not only existing applications are foreseeing the benefits of utilizing the developments in this area but also new kinds of opportunities are emerging in different fields e.g customer insights, check brand affinity, monitor internet content, fraud detection, surveillance, autonomous driving, and predictive maintenance.

Traditional system-level architectures employ Edge and cloud computing as separate entities because of a number of challenges; limited resources on edge, reliability, latency, and security aspect associated with communication between edge and cloud computing. With respect to the system architecture, generally, two implementation strategies are employed for applications involving edge or cloud computing. We will explain it with an example application as shown in Figure-1. The application has two temperature sensors and an actuator/heat sink fan with a number of processes to handle the data. The data passes through a pipeline in order to make an intelligent decision to control the actuator. For the given application, two implementation strategies can be devised using traditional approach.
In the first strategy as shown in Figure-2, all required processing is performed on the edge device and final features are sent to an end-user or a machine as shown in Figure-1.
Applications with real-time requirements, reliability, and security concerns make the best use of this strategy. A particular use-case is autonomous driving and industrial robots.

In the second strategy, raw data is transmitted to the cloud/host and all required processing is performed on the cloud/host as shown in Figure-3. In this strategy, no local processing is performed on the edge and raw data is transmitted/transferred to the cloud for processing.
Applications with requirements for big-data analysis, predictive maintenance, inventory creation, customer insights, and legal storage make the best use of this strategy.

For certain applications, a better alternative is to distribute the processing load between two-points; the edge device and cloud/host as shown in Figure-4. It is important to find a trade-off between processing and communication for different factors such as latency, throughput, and cost.

Applications that require scalability, reduced cost, longer product life cycle, and forsee shorter updates time makes the best use of this strategy. We will elaborate on this implementation strategy with an example application; people counting on a pedestrian crossing.

How many people are passing by a pedestrian crossing?. A smart camera detects the number of people on a pedestrian crossing near a supermarket for data analytics. The processing pipeline for the application is shown in Figure-5, starting with pre-processing to feature extraction for analytics. In this application, a better implementation strategy is to partition the processing load between the edge and the cloud as shown in Figure-6. The low-level tasks; temporal and spatial filtering and segmentation are performed on the edge and high-level tasks; feature extraction, classification, and analytics are performed on the cloud. The edge computing architecture for the system is shown in Figure-7, it involves preprocessing functions together with bi-level video encoding in order to make the data suitable for communication.

In relation to architecture for machine learning applications, there are often two strategies being conceived. In the first strategy, data is captured and transmitted/transferred to a cloud/host for further processing whereas in the second strategy, all required vision tasks are performed on the edge device and only the final features are transmitted to the cloud/host. We have discussed that the implementation strategies are application dependant and that a third strategy should be considered during the architecture space exploration. In the third strategy, the load is distributed between the edge device and cloud computing. This not only reduces the processing requirement on the edge but also makes the product life cycle longer as new adjustments could be done easily on the cloud. Depending on the application, the right architectural decision can give a better trade-off between cost and functionality.
